conclusion: Ball A exerts no force on the rod at the highest point.
The gravitational force acting on ball A is mg.
At the highest point, the centripetal force required to keep ball A in circular motion is provided entirely by gravity: mg = mv_A^2/L.
Ball B is at the lowest point when ball A is at the highest point.
The gravitational force on ball B is mg.
The centripetal force required to keep ball B in circular motion at the lowest point is: F_B - mg = mv_B^2/2L.
The total mechanical energy of the system is conserved.
At the highest point of ball A: E = mgh_A + 1/2 mv_A^2, with h_A = 2L.
Calculate energy at the highest point: E = 2mgL + 1/2 mgL = 5/2 mgL.
At the lowest point of ball B: E = mgh_B + 1/2 mv_B^2, with h_B = 0.
Equating the energy at both points: 1/2 mv_B^2 = 5/2 mgL.
Substitute v_B^2 back into the equation for the centripetal force: F_B - mg = m(5gL)/2L.
The force exerted by ball B on the rod when ball A reaches the highest point is F_B = 7mg/2.
